{"step_by_step_thinking": "Eisenmenger syndrome is characterized by pulmonary hypertension and a reversal of a left-to-right shunt to a right-to-left shunt. Let's go through each option:

A. Pulmonary veins are not distended: This is true. In Eisenmenger syndrome, the pulmonary veins are not distended because the blood flow is redirected from the right side of the heart to the left side.

B. RV & LV walls come back to normal size: This is false. In Eisenmenger syndrome, the right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) undergo hypertrophy due to the increased workload.

C. Dilatation of central pulmonary artery: This is true. In Eisenmenger syndrome, there is dilatation of the central pulmonary artery due to the increased pulmonary arterial pressure.
